user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of completed_callback:
```c
static void
completed_callback (void *cls,
                    struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    void **req_cls,
                    enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct timeval *tv = *req_cls;
  struct timeval tve;
  uint64_t delta;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == tv)
    return;
  gettimeofday (&tve, NULL);

  delta = ((uint64_t) (tve.tv_sec - tv->tv_sec)) * 1000000LL
          + (uint64_t) tve.tv_usec - (uint64_t) tv->tv_usec;
  if (delta < SMALL)
    small_deltas[delta]++;
  else
    fprintf (stdout, "D: %" PRIu64 " 1\n", delta);
  free (tv);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the Standard Library string handling functions from <string.h> are present in the provided code fragment. The code contains calls to gettimeofday, fprintf, free and uses an array index small_deltas[delta], pointer dereference of *req_cls to obtain a struct timeval, and integer arithmetic; none invoke memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn (or other <string.h> functions) that could cause accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by pointer parameters. Therefore Rule 21.17 (use of <string.h> functions) has no direct applicability here and there are no fragments to investigate for that rule. Note: the array indexing small_deltas[delta] and similar bounds concerns are relevant to other MISRA rules about array bounds and integer conversions, but they are outside the scope of Rule 21.17 and so are not included as suspicious fragments for this specific rule.
